books.title: After-the-Cure

books.description: "After the Cure" by Deirdre Gould is a post-apocalyptic science fiction novel where a plague has swept the Earth, turning people into violent "Infected." Years later, a cure is found, and those who were infected begin to regain their memories of the horrific acts they committed. The story follows a court psychologist and a defense attorney as society attempts to rebuild and judge those responsible for the plague, exploring themes of survival, memory, and the complexities of justice in a world forever changed.

books.title: The Terror
books.author: Arthur Machen
books.description:
"The Terror" is a novel by Arthur Machen, a prominent writer of supernatural and weird fiction. The book is a chilling and atmospheric tale that explores the breakdown of the natural order and humanity's place within it.

The story is set during World War I, but the horror isn't from the battlefield. Instead, a series of mysterious and brutal killings begins to plague the British countryside. People are found dead, mangled and torn apart, with no clear explanation or human culprit. The victims are varied: children, sailors, and even soldiers in training. The circumstances are always strange—a child is killed while playing, a fisherman is found in his boat with a look of extreme terror on his face.

As the mysterious deaths continue, an official investigation is launched, but it yields no answers. Rumors and whispers of an unseen force, a "terror," begin to spread. The investigators, including the main protagonist, a man named Dyson, are forced to confront the terrifying possibility that the natural world itself has turned against humanity. The animals of the countryside—the birds, the farm animals, the wild creatures—are behaving strangely, and there is a growing suspicion that they are somehow involved in the escalating violence.

Machen masterfully builds suspense by withholding a definitive answer. The true nature of "The Terror" is never explicitly revealed, but the suggestion is that humanity, through the act of a great war, has disturbed a primal, ancient force of nature. The horror lies in the idea that the seemingly innocent world of fields and forests has become a hunting ground, and that man, with all his technology and civilization, is no longer the master of his own domain.

books.title: Kim
books.author: Rudyard Kipling
books.description: Rudyard Kipling's "Kim" is a classic adventure and espionage novel set in British India, following the orphaned Irish boy Kim as he grows up on the streets, becomes a disciple to a Tibetan lama, and is eventually drawn into "The Great Game" as a spy for the British Secret Service.

books.title: The-Time-Machine
books.author: H. G. Wells
books.description: H.G. Wells's "The Time Machine" is a groundbreaking science fiction novel about a Victorian scientist who invents a device to travel through time. He journeys far into the distant future to the year 802,701 AD, where he discovers humanity has devolved into two distinct species, the gentle, childlike Eloi and the subterranean, monstrous Morlocks, revealing a stark and chilling vision of the future shaped by social class divisions.

books.title: The Master Key System
books.author: Charles F. Haanel
books.description: The Master Key System (1912) by Charles F. Haanel is a groundbreaking work on personal success, mental discipline, and the power of thought. Originally published as a correspondence course, it guides readers through 24 lessons that build a system for harnessing creative visualization, concentration, and positive thinking to achieve success and self-mastery. Often regarded as a cornerstone of modern self-help and motivational literature, it has influenced countless thinkers and authors, including those behind The Secret.

books.title: Ishq Zair Ishq Zabar
books.author: Sumaira Hameed
books.description: A soulful romantic Urdu novel, Ishq Zair Ishq Zabar explores the depths of love, sacrifice, and inner struggle. Sumaira Hameed weaves a poetic and emotional story that leaves a lasting impact on the reader’s heart.

books.title: Jannat Ke Pattay
books.author: Nemrah Ahmed
books.description: Jannat Ke Pattay is a gripping Urdu novel by Nemrah Ahmed that blends mystery, romance, and spiritual awakening. The story follows the journey of Haya Suleman, a bold girl whose life changes after she uncovers deep secrets and is drawn into the world of espionage. With powerful Islamic lessons and emotional depth, this novel is both inspiring and suspenseful.

books.title: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer
books.author: Mark Twain
books.description: The Adventures of Tom Sawyer is a timeless classic by Mark Twain, translated into Urdu. The novel follows the mischievous and adventurous young boy Tom as he navigates life along the Mississippi River. From treasure hunts to witnessing mysterious events, this story is packed with humor, thrills, and important life lessons for readers of all ages.

books.title: Hunger
books.author: Knut Hamsun
books.description: A deeply introspective and haunting account of a man’s descent into hunger and mental instability. Through poetic, fragmented narration, Hamsun paints a raw and gripping picture of a person pushed to the edge by physical and emotional deprivation.

books.title: The-Man-on-the-Other-Side
books.author: Ada Barnett
books.description: Ada Barnett's "The Man on the Other Side," published in 1922, is a British literary and historical novel that delves into the profound connection between a woman and her new home. The narrative centers on Ruth Courthope Seer, a woman in her forties who, after a challenging life, finally realizes her dream of owning Thorpe Farm in the serene English countryside. As Ruth cultivates her land and settles into its rhythms, she develops a mysterious and powerful bond with the farm's history and its previous owner, hinting at a spiritual or paranormal presence. Through Ruth's journey, Barnett explores universal themes of love, loss, grief, and the quiet healing power of nature and belonging, set against the backdrop of post-World War I rural England.

books.title: The Divine Comedy of Dante Alighieri
books.author: Dante Alighieri
books.description: The Divine Comedy is an epic poem written by Italian poet Dante Alighieri in the 14th century. It narrates the journey of the soul through Hell (Inferno), Purgatory (Purgatorio), and Heaven (Paradiso). This Urdu translation presents Dante’s powerful vision of the afterlife, spiritual redemption, and divine justice, making it accessible to Urdu readers while preserving the poetic depth of the original.

books.title: Around-the-World-in-80-Days
books.author: Jules Verne
books.description: Jules Verne's "Around the World in 80 Days" is a classic adventure novel that chronicles the extraordinary journey of the meticulous English gentleman Phileas Fogg and his new French valet, Passepartout. Driven by an audacious £20,000 wager made at London's Reform Club, Fogg sets out to circumnavigate the globe in precisely eighty days, leveraging the cutting-edge transportation technologies of the Victorian era, such as steamships and railways. Their whirlwind voyage takes them across continents and oceans, from Egypt and India to China, Japan, and America, encountering a diverse array of cultures and unexpected challenges, including rescuing an Indian princess and evading a persistent detective, Fix, who mistakenly believes Fogg is a bank robber. The novel is a thrilling race against time, blending meticulous planning with unforeseen obstacles, ultimately culminating in a surprising twist that highlights the subjective nature of time and the true value of human connection over mere triumph.

books.title: richard-francis-burton_vikram-and-the-vampire
books.author: Richard Francis Burton
books.description: "Vikram and the Vampire" by Sir Richard Francis Burton is a captivating collection of ancient Indian folk tales, translated and adapted from the Sanskrit Vetala Panchavimshati. The central frame story follows the legendary King Vikram, who is tasked with transporting a cunning and philosophical vampire-like spirit (Vetala) to a sorcerer. During their journey, the Vetala narrates a series of intricate and often morally complex stories, each concluding with a riddle or a dilemma that King Vikram must solve. If he answers, the Vetala flies back to its tree, forcing Vikram to recapture it; if he knows the answer but remains silent, his head will burst. This ongoing challenge creates a cycle of adventure, wit, and profound reflection, as the tales delve into themes of human nature, justice, sacrifice, and the intricacies of right and wrong, all steeped in the rich supernatural and philosophical traditions of Indian mythology.

books.title: The-Slayer-of-Souls
books.author: Robert W. Chambers
books.description:
The Slayer of Souls (1920) is an occult thriller about Tressa Norne, an American woman who escapes captivity from a mystical and murderous secret cult in Asia. She returns to the United States hoping for peace—but instead finds herself drawn into a deadly conflict involving psychic powers, Eastern mysticism, government espionage, and ancient evil.

Tressa has been trained by her captors in the ways of mental domination and dark arts, but now she uses her knowledge against them as a secret weapon in the fight for justice. Her unusual talents attract the attention of the U.S. government, and she becomes a vital player in a secret war against sorcery and treachery.

This fast-paced novel combines action, romance, and supernatural horror in the early pulp tradition, and features a strong, mysterious female lead—rare for its time.

books.title: The Hamlet
books.author: William Cuthbert Faulkner
books.description:
The Hamlet is both an ironic take on classical tragedy and a mordant commentary on the grand pretensions of the antebellum South and the depths of its decay in the aftermath of war and Reconstruction. It tells of the advent and the rise of the Snopes family in Frenchman’s Bend, a small town built on the ruins of a once-stately plantation. Flem Snopes—wily, energetic, a man of shady origins—quickly comes to dominate the city and its people with his cunning and guile.—Goodreads.com

William Cuthbert Faulkner (September 25, 1897 – July 6, 1962) was an American writer and Nobel Prize laureate from Oxford, Mississippi. Faulkner wrote novels, short stories, a play, poetry, essays, and screenplays. He is primarily known for his novels and short stories set in the fictional Yoknapatawpha County, based on Lafayette County, Mississippi, where he spent most of his life.

Faulkner is one of the most celebrated writers in American literature, generally and Southern literature specifically. Though his work was published as early as 1919 and largely during the 1920s and 1930s, Faulkner was relatively unknown until receiving the 1949 Nobel Prize in Literature, for which he became the only Mississippi-born Nobel laureate. Two of his works, A Fable (1954) and his last novel The Reivers (1962), won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. In 1998, the Modern Library ranked his 1929 novel The Sound and the Fury sixth on its list of the 100 best English-language novels of the 20th century; also on the list were As I Lay Dying (1930) and Light in August (1932). Absalom, Absalom! (1936) is often included on similar lists.--Wikipedia.

The narrative follows her well-intentioned but often misguided romantic meddling, leading to humorous misunderstandings, social embarrassments, and lessons learned about humility, self-awareness, and the true nature of love. Through Emma's journey of personal growth, Austen delivers a witty and insightful commentary on social class, marriage, and the complexities of human relationships in Regency England.

books.title: Jesting Pilate The Diary of a Journey
books.author: Huxley, Aldous Leonard
books.description:
The author recounts his experiences in the mid-1920s, traveling through several countries (India, Burma, Malaya, Japan, and the United States), and offers his observations on their people, cultures, and customs.

Aldous Leonard Huxley (26 July 1894 – 22 November 1963) was an English writer, novelist, philosopher, and a prominent member of the Huxley family.

He was best known for his novels, including Brave New World, set in a dystopian London, and for non-fiction books, such as The Doors of Perception, which recounts experiences after taking a psychedelic drug, and a wide-ranging output of essays. Early in his career, Huxley edited the magazine Oxford Poetry and published short stories and poetry.

Huxley completed his first (unpublished) novel at the age of 17 and began writing seriously in his early 20s, establishing himself as a successful writer and social satirist. His first published novels were social satires: Crome Yellow (1921), Antic Hay (1923), Those Barren Leaves (1925), and Point Counter Point (1928). Brave New World was Huxley's fifth novel and first dystopian work. In the 1920s, he was also a contributor to Vanity Fair and British Vogue magazines.--Wikipedia.

Set within a privileged household, the story revolves around rivalry, jealousy, and betrayal, exploring how family politics and envy strain relationships.

* **Mehreen**, orphaned and sensitive, struggles under her family's judgment due to her father’s past.
* **Mashal**, outwardly charming and analytical, harbors deep envy of Mehreen’s talents and attractiveness, which grows into emotionally harmful behavior.
* **Aswad**, caught between them, falls under Mashal's influence and misjudges Mehreen—leading to devastating consequences including Mashal’s suicide and traumatic fallout ([dailytimes.com.pk][1], [showbizhut.com][2]).

Through its intense emotional drama, the novel highlights themes of trust, societal expectations, mental health, and redemption. With its tightly woven plot, psychological complexity, and moral insight, it offers a thoughtful commentary on the dangers of trusting appearances and the importance of forgiveness .

books.title: Increasing-Efficiency-In-Business
books.author: Walter Dill Scott
books.description: Increasing Efficiency in Business is a practical guide that explores proven methods to enhance productivity, streamline operations, and boost profitability. Designed for business owners, managers, and professionals, this book covers time-tested strategies for improving workflow, embracing technology, motivating teams, and cutting waste in daily operations. Whether you're running a small enterprise or managing a large team, this book offers tools to optimize performance and achieve sustainable success.

books.title: Hazel-Squirrel
books.author: Howard B. Famous
books.description: Hazel Squirrel and Other Stories" is a charming collection of short animal tales designed for young readers. Each story features woodland creatures like squirrels, owls, rabbits, and chipmunks living in a forest. Hazel Squirrel, the main character in the title story, is a kind, curious, and sometimes mischievous young squirrel who learns lessons about friendship, helpfulness, and responsibility.

books.title: Dunsany - The King of Elfland's Daughter
books.author: Lord Dunsany
books.description: A poetic fantasy novel by Lord Dunsany, first published in 1924, about a mortal prince who journeys into the mystical realm of Elfland to marry the elf king’s daughter. The story explores magic, love, and the clash between the human world and the enchanted realm.
books.file_name: Dunsany - The King of Elfland's Daughter.pdf

books.title: Khuda ki bastiخدا کی بستی۔
books.author: Shaukat Siddiqui
books.description: ***Khuda Ki Basti*** by **Shaukat Siddiqui** is a powerful Urdu novel set in post-partition Pakistan. It tells the story of a poor family living in the slums of Karachi, highlighting issues like poverty, exploitation, corruption, and social injustice. Through its compelling characters, especially the orphan siblings Sultana and Anwar, the novel portrays the harsh realities of urban life and the struggles of the underprivileged. It is considered a modern classic of Urdu literature.

books.title: Junior Ranger Spaceflight Explorer – Explorer’s Activity Guide
books.author: NASA & U.S. National Park Service
books.description: The Junior Ranger Spaceflight Explorer Activity Guide is a free, NASA-developed booklet that teaches kids about rockets, lunar missions, and space technology through fun puzzles and hands-on activities. It connects space science with real-world national parks, making STEM learning interactive and memorable.

books.title: Beethoven
books.author: Thomas Tapper
books.description: This short biography introduces young readers to the early life of Ludwig van Beethoven. Written in a simple and engaging style, the book highlights how Beethoven, though sometimes reluctant, developed his musical genius through dedication and hard work. It’s part of the "Child's Own Book of Great Musicians" series by Thomas Tapper, designed to inspire children with the life stories of great composers.

books.title: Bill-the-Minder
books.author: William Heath Robinson
books.description: Bill the Minder follows a clever boy named Bill and his cousins as they travel the countryside helping quirky people solve unusual problems. Bill invents funny and imaginative machines to fix each issue, making the story a fun mix of adventure, humor, and invention.

books.title: MOTHER TERESA
books.author: Meg Greene
books.description: "Mother Teresa: A Biography" by Meg Greene explores the life of Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu, from her Albanian birth to her global recognition as Mother Teresa. The book delves into her transformation into a nun, her dedication to caring for the sick and dying in Calcutta, and the founding and expansion of the Missionaries of Charity. It also examines the scrutiny and criticism surrounding her work, including her ideology, methods, and financing, as well as her controversial beatification.

books.title: Voices from the Past
books.author: Paul Alexander Bartlett
books.description: "A collection of five historical novels written in the form of journals by the Greek poet Sappho of Lesbos, Christ, Leonardo da Vinci, Shakespeare, and Lincoln, integrating their thought, writings, and the testimony of others"--Provided by publisher.

books.title: California Mexican Spanish Cook Book
books.author: Bertha Haffner‑Ginger
books.description: This is a charming early 20th-century cookbook—published around 1914—showcasing authentic Mexican and Spanish dishes as prepared in California. Written from the author's own experience learning from local cooks, it includes recipes like enchiladas, tamales, chile sauces, Spanish soups, salads, tamale pie, tortillas, and desserts. Beyond recipes, the book provides cultural context, photographs, and vivid descriptions that transport readers to San Francisco kitchens of a century past

books.title: Ladies-and-Gentlemen...The-Redeemers
books.author: Michael Scott Miller
books.description: Bert Ingram, a former music industry rep who has lost his passion and footing, embarks on a quest for redemption. He assembles a ragtag band of street and subway performers in San Francisco—each member battling personal challenges. Despite their rocky beginnings and clashing personalities, together they discover the transformative power of music, hope, and mutual support. A warm-hearted, character-driven story of dreams, second chances, and the unifying power of collaboration.

books.title: Business-Hints-for-Men-and-Women
books.author: Alfred Rochefort Calhoun
books.description: This practical guide offers timeless advice for both men and women navigating the business world. Written in the early 20th century, it includes tips on personal conduct, professional etiquette, communication, and how to develop habits that lead to success. Its concise and clear insights remain relevant for readers interested in classic business wisdom.

books.title: saMas Kids' Mag – Vol. 1, Issue 1 (Oct 2024)
books.author: Children Magazine Editorial Team
books.description: saMas Charity Children magazine English volume 1 issue 1 (Oct 2024)

books.title: Barrie_Peter_Pan_and_Wendy
books.author: J. M. Barrie
books.description: “Peter Pan and Wendy” is a timeless fantasy novel by J. M. Barrie about a magical boy who never grows up. Peter takes Wendy and her brothers to Neverland, a world filled with fairies, pirates, mermaids, and adventure. Together, they battle the infamous Captain Hook and learn about childhood, imagination, and the joy of never growing old.

books.title: Chocolate-and-Cocoa-Recipes
books.author: Maria Parloa and Janet McKenzie Hill
books.description: Originally published in 1909, this classic cookbook offers a delightful collection of recipes focused on chocolate, cocoa, and homemade candy. Compiled by renowned culinary experts Maria Parloa and Janet McKenzie Hill, the book was sponsored by Walter Baker & Co., one of America’s oldest chocolate manufacturers. It features traditional methods for preparing cocoa-based beverages, cakes, fudge, toffee, fondant, and other sweets, all presented with period charm and vintage culinary techniques.

books.title: A-Pair-of-Schoolgirls
books.author: Angela Brazil
books.description: "A Pair of Schoolgirls: A Story of School Days" by Angela Brazil, published in 1912, is a pioneering work in the girls' school story genre, offering a vibrant and authentic portrayal of early 20th-century British boarding school life. The novel follows the experiences of its young protagonists, exploring their friendships, rivalries, and the daily routines within a structured academic setting, often with a focus on youthful mischief and character development. Brazil's lively prose captures the spirit of adolescence and the unique atmosphere of a girls' school, presenting themes of camaraderie, self-discovery, and navigating social dynamics that resonate even today, solidifying its place as a classic and influential piece of children's literature.

books.title: Lady Susan
books.author: Jane Austen
books.description: "Lady Susan" is one of Jane Austen's earliest and most distinctive works, written around 1794 but published posthumously in 1871. Presented entirely in the form of epistolary correspondence—a series of letters between characters—the novel offers a sharp, satirical portrait of its eponymous anti-heroine, Lady Susan Vernon. A beautiful, charming, and utterly unscrupulous widow, Lady Susan skillfully manipulates those around her, including family and potential suitors, to secure her own financial and social advantage. This witty and cynical novella stands apart from Austen's more well-known romances, providing a fascinating glimpse into a more morally ambiguous side of Regency society and a complex female character who challenges conventional notions of virtue and propriety.

books.title: Artists'-Wives
books.author: Alphonse Daudet
books.description: Artists’ Wives is a collection of fictional sketches by French author Alphonse Daudet that explores the often difficult lives of women married to artists—painters, poets, sculptors, and musicians. Through separate, character-driven stories, Daudet examines the emotional toll of living in the shadow of creative genius, portraying relationships marked by sacrifice, neglect, jealousy, and artistic obsession.

books.title: Tum Hi Meri Mihabat Thy
books.author: Dilawaiz Rajpoot
books.description: Novel Based Possasive Hero ,Most Romantic Novel, Gangster ,Innocent Heroine ,After marriage Love story
books.file_name: Tum Hi Meri Mihabat Thy By Dilawaiz Rajpoot_compressed.pdf

books.title: The-Swiss-Family-Robinson
books.author: Johann David Wyss
books.description: A classic survival adventure tale, The Swiss Family Robinson follows a Swiss family shipwrecked on a deserted island. Using their wits and knowledge, they build a new life in the wild, facing challenges and discovering the wonders of nature. The story teaches resilience, creativity, and the importance of family unity.

books.title: The-Invisible-Man
books.author: H. G. Wells
books.description: "The Invisible Man," a seminal work by H.G. Wells published in 1897, is a chilling science fiction novel that explores the perilous consequences of unchecked scientific ambition and the corrupting nature of absolute power. The story follows Griffin, a brilliant but arrogant scientist who discovers a formula for invisibility. His initial triumph quickly descends into a reign of terror as he uses his newfound ability for petty crimes and ultimately, a desperate attempt to establish dominance over humanity. Blending elements of horror and social commentary, the novel delves into themes of isolation, morality, and the psychological decay that can accompany radical scientific advancement.

books.title: Abbas Invoice
books.author: Alliance Homes
books.description: Invoice of an estimate to professionally re-level a mobile home.

books.title: Part Two-saMas Kids' Mag, Vol. 3, Issue 2, (April 2025)

books.description: saMas Charity Children Magazine-Volume 3, Issue 2, (April 2025) Part Two

books.title: Decline
books.author: Edward Gibbon
books.description: "The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire" is a six-volume historical work by Edward Gibbon, detailing the trajectory of the Roman Empire from its peak to its eventual fall. Gibbon explores the factors contributing to the empire's decline, including barbarian invasions, internal discord, and the rise of Christianity. The book spans thirteen centuries, encompassing the Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Empire and the rise of Islam and the Mongol Empire

books.title: A Short History of Science
books.author: William Cecil Dampier
books.description: A Short History of Science by W.C. Dampier is a concise and accessible overview of the development of science from ancient times to the early 20th century. Covering fields like physics, chemistry, astronomy, and biology, this classic work explains how human understanding of the natural world evolved over centuries. It’s a valuable resource for students, educators, and anyone interested in the roots of modern science.

books.title: A History of Ancient Egypt PDF
books.author: John Romer
books.description: Ancient Egypt was a civilization that flourished along the Nile River in North Africa for over 3,000 years, from around 3100 BC to 30 BC. It is renowned for its impressive achievements in architecture, writing, governance, and art, leaving behind a rich legacy of pyramids, temples, and intricate artwork. The civilization is often divided into three main periods of prosperity: the Old, Middle, and New Kingdoms, separated by intermediate periods of instability.
books.file_name: A History of Ancient Egypt PDF.pdf

books.title: Bill-the-Minder
books.author: William Heath Robinso
books.description: Bill the Minder follows a clever boy named Bill and his cousins as they travel the countryside helping quirky people solve unusual problems. Bill invents funny and imaginative machines to fix each issue, making the story a fun mix of adventure, humor, and invention.

books.title: Thomas Young-The Boy Who Knew Almost Everything
books.author: Syed Ali Bilgrami 🖋
books.description: Imagine a boy who could read before he could ride a bike—meet Thomas Young, the ultimate knowledge adventurer! Born in 1773 in England, Thomas was a tiny genius: reading by age two, devouring the Bible twice by four 📖, and mastering over a dozen languages (like Arabic, Greek, and Persian!) as a teen. Friends called him the “Walking Encyclopedia,” but he wasn’t just a bookworm—he danced, rode horses 🐎, and once trekked 170 miles to see an art show!
books.file_name: Thomas Young-The Boy Who Knew Almost Everything.pdf

books.title: Physics – An Introduction for Early Grades
books.author: Bel Richardson
books.description: Physics – An Introduction for Early Grades introduces young kids to basic physics concepts like matter, energy, forces, and heat using simple language and fun illustrations. It helps children understand how the physical world works in an easy and engaging way.

books.title: A Short History of Science
books.author: William Cecil Dampier
books.description: A Short History of Science by W.C. Dampier is a concise and accessible overview of the development of science from ancient times to the early 20th century. Covering fields like physics, chemistry, astronomy, and biology, this classic work explains how human understanding of the natural world evolved over centuries. It’s a valuable resource for students, educators, and anyone interested in the roots of modern science.

books.title: Collected-Works-of-Poe
books.author: Edgar Allan Poe
books.description: "Collected Works of Poe" compiles the extensive and influential writings of Edgar Allan Poe, a towering figure in 19th-century American literature. This collection typically includes his groundbreaking short stories, which span genres from the chilling psychological horror of "The Tell-Tale Heart" and "The Fall of the House of Usher," to the foundational detective fiction of "The Murders in the Rue Morgue." Alongside these tales, the works feature his evocative and often dark poetry, such as "The Raven" and "Annabel Lee," showcasing his mastery of rhythm and symbolism. Overall, the collection provides a comprehensive view of Poe's unique genius, marked by themes of madness, death, beauty, and the macabre, solidifying his legacy as a master of gothic and suspenseful storytelling.

books.title: Aankhain Bheeg Jati Hain
books.author: Syed Wasi Shah.
books.description: "Aankhain Bheeg Jati Hain" by Syed Wasi Shah is a popular poetry collection. It features various poems, and is known to include the famous poem "Kangan." The book is cherished for its lyrical quality and emotional depth, characteristic of Wasi Shah's style.

books.title: Matilda
books.author: Roald dahl
books.description: "Matilda" by Roald Dahl tells the story of a young, exceptionally intelligent girl named Matilda Wormwood who is neglected by her parents and mistreated by her school's headmistress, Miss Trunchbull. Matilda discovers she has telekinetic powers, which she uses to stand up to the injustices she faces and to help her kind teacher, Miss Honey.

books.title: Boy: Tales of Childhood
books.author: Roald dahl
books.description: Boy: Tales of Childhood" by Roald Dahl is an autobiography that recounts his early life, from his childhood in Wales and England to his time at boarding school and his first job with Royal Dutch Shell. The book details Dahl's experiences with family, school, and the wider world, including humorous and sometimes painful anecdotes that shaped his perspective and later influenced his writing. It's known for its engaging style, relatable stories, and insightful look into Dahl's formative years

books.title: Think Like A Scientist
books.author: Brandon Green
books.description: HAVE YOU EVER WONDERED WHAT IT TAKES TO BE A SCIENTIST? JACK HADN'T, BUT AFTER HIS FATHER CONTRACTED COVID19, HE DEVELOPED LONG COVID, WHICH INVOLVED A VARIETY OF CHRONIC HEALTH ISSUES MOLD TOXICITY, LYME DISEASE, CANDIDA - OVERGROWTH, S.I.B.O, MAST CELL ACTIVATION SYNDROME, MULTIPLE CHEMICAL SENSITIVITY. ELECTROMAGNETIC SENSITIVITY, CHRONIC FATIGUE SYNDROME, AND LIGHT SENSITIVITY. HIS DETERIORATING HEALTH WAS SOMETHING MOST DOCTORS HAD NEVER SEEN BEFORE AND COULDN'T UNDERSTAND. JACK'S FATHER WENT ON QUITE A ROUGH JOURNEY THAT ENDED WITH HIM BEING SENT TO THE PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL! WITH THE HELP OF DATA, HIS FATHER, AND THE OPINION OF EXPERTS THAT MADE THE MOST SENSE TO HIM, JACK APPLIED CRITICAL THINKING, THINKING LIKE A SCIENTIST, TO SAVE THE DAY!

books.title: it-by-stephen-king
books.author: Stephen-king
books.description: "It" by Stephen King is a horror novel about a shape-shifting monster, often appearing as Pennywise the Clown, that preys on children in Derry, Maine. A group of seven childhood outcasts, the "Losers' Club," first battle It in 1958 and then reunite as adults in 1985 to defeat it permanently. The book explores themes of childhood trauma, the power of friendship, and confronting evil.

books.title: Building Customer Relationships
books.author: Jagdish N. Sheth
books.description: Building customer relationships is the process of creating strong, lasting connections with customers by understanding their needs, providing consistent value, and fostering trust. It helps increase loyalty, satisfaction, and long-term business success.

books.title: The-Magic-Finger
books.author: Roald dahl
books.description: "The Magic Finger" by Roald Dahl tells the story of an unnamed eight-year-old girl who lives next to the Gregg family, who enjoy hunting. When the girl gets angry, her magic finger activates, causing bizarre transformations. After the Greggs repeatedly go hunting, the girl uses her magic finger, turning the Greggs into birds and the ducks they hunted into human-sized creatures. The story explores themes of empathy, anger, and the consequences of one's actions.

books.title: The Lean Startup - Erick Ries
books.author: Sarah Mitchell
books.description: Discover inspiring journeys of entrepreneurs who turned ideas into successful businesses. This book shares real-world lessons, challenges, and strategies to motivate and guide aspiring founders on their startup path.

books.title: A-Little-Book-for-A-Little-Cook
books.author: L. P. Hubbard
books.description: A Little Book for a Little Cook is a charming early 20th-century cookbook designed especially for young girls who are learning to cook. First published in 1905, the book introduces simple recipes that children can prepare with minimal supervision—perfect for teaching basic cooking skills and encouraging confidence in the kitchen.

books.title: Cornwall
books.author: G. E. Mitton
books.description: Cornwall is a travel and cultural guide written in the early 20th century by G. E. Mitton. The book presents a rich description of the Cornish landscape, history, legends, and daily life. From coastal cliffs to fishing villages and moorlands, the author paints a vivid picture of Cornwall’s beauty and spirit. Historical references, local customs, and regional charm are interwoven to create a well-rounded introduction to the county.

books.title: Moreno-Garcia-Silvia-Mexican-Gothic-
books.author: Silvia Moreno
books.description: Mexican Gothic" by Silvia Moreno-Garcia is a gothic horror novel set in 1950s Mexico, where a young socialite, Noemí Taboada, investigates a mysterious letter from her newly-wed cousin, Catalina, who claims her husband is trying to murder her. Noemi travels to High Place, a remote mansion, and uncovers dark secrets about the Doyle family, their eugenics-obsessed patriarch, and the house's sinister influence. The novel explores themes of sexism, female independence, and power, while blending elements of romance, history, mystery, and horror.

books.title: Riders-to-the-Sea
books.author: John Millington (J. M.) Synge
books.description: A deeply moving exploration of human resilience in the face of inevitable tragedy. Synge uses spare, poetic dialogue and cultural authenticity to highlight themes of grief, resignation, and the unforgiving power of nature.

books.title: The-Aliens
books.author: Murray Leinster (pseudonym of William Fitzgerald Jenkins)
books.description:
The Aliens is a classic science fiction novella first published in 1959 by Murray Leinster, one of the pioneers of early sci-fi. The story explores the aftermath of Earth’s first contact with an alien species—creatures that are not hostile, but so different from humans that communication and mutual understanding seem almost impossible.

The narrative follows how diplomacy, science, and human determination are put to the test in trying to avoid interstellar conflict. It’s a thoughtful exploration of xenophobia, cultural misunderstanding, and the hope of peaceful coexistence.

books.title: james-and-the-giant-peach-by-roald-dahl
books.author: Roald dahl
books.description: The story follows James Henry Trotter, a young orphan who lives with his cruel aunts, Spiker and Sponge. After receiving a mysterious package of magic crocodile tongues, James accidentally spills them near an old peach tree, causing a giant peach to grow. Inside the peach, James discovers a group of human-sized, talking insects: Grasshopper, Centipede, Ladybug, Spider, Earthworm, and Miss Spider. Together, they embark on a fantastical journey across the Atlantic Ocean in the giant peach, encountering various adventures and challenges along the way.

books.title: Robinson-Crusoe
books.author: Daniel Defoe
books.description: "Robinson Crusoe" by Daniel Defoe, first published in 1719, is a seminal adventure novel widely regarded as one of the earliest and most influential works of English literature. The story chronicles the extraordinary ordeal of Robinson Crusoe, a young Englishman who, after a shipwreck, finds himself stranded alone on a remote tropical island for twenty-eight years. Through his meticulous efforts, resourcefulness, and deep resilience, Crusoe transforms his desolate environment, building a shelter, cultivating crops, and domesticating animals, ultimately creating a functional society of one. Beyond the thrilling narrative of survival, the novel delves into themes of self-reliance, the relationship between man and nature, colonialism, and spiritual awakening, cementing its status as a timeless classic of human ingenuity and endurance.

books.title: Helen Keller - Story of My Life
books.author: Helen Keller
books.description: "The Story of My Life," published in 1903, is the remarkable autobiography of Helen Keller, a celebrated American author, activist, and lecturer. The book chronicles her extraordinary early life, detailing her profound isolation and frustration after an illness at 19 months old left her blind and deaf. It vividly recounts the pivotal moment when, at the age of seven, her teacher Anne Sullivan arrived and, through tireless dedication, broke through the barriers of silence and darkness by teaching Helen to communicate through touch and language. A powerful testament to the resilience of the human spirit and the transformative power of education, the memoir also includes selections of Keller's letters and supplementary accounts from Sullivan, offering an intimate and inspiring glimpse into the journey that liberated a brilliant mind.

books.title: Knowing-the-Angels
books.author: Muhammad-Al-Jibaly
books.description: The "Anjil" referred to in an Islamic context is understood to be the holy book revealed to Prophet Jesus (Isa), peace be upon him, according to the Quran. However, Muslims believe this "Anjil" is distinct from the New Testament, and instead refers to an original Gospel given to Jesus by Allah. It's a central concept in Islamic belief, with its teachings being considered part of God's divine message alongside the Torah and Zabur (revealed to Moses and David, respectively

books.title: The-Complete-Works-of-William-Shakespeare
books.author: William Shakespeare
books.description: A comprehensive collection of Shakespeare’s timeless works that have shaped literature, theatre, and storytelling for centuries. This edition preserves the original texts, offering readers full access to his poetic language, memorable characters, and universal themes.

books.title: Self-Help
books.author: Samuel Smiles
books.description: A classic motivational guide rooted in Victorian values, Self-Help promotes the belief that anyone can rise in life through effort, honesty, and character. It laid the foundation for the entire self-improvement genre and remains a powerful read today.

books.title: The-Jungle-Book
books.author: Rudyard Kipling
books.description: The Jungle Book is a collection of short stories written by Rudyard Kipling, first published in 1894. Set in the Indian jungle, it follows the adventures of Mowgli, a human child raised by wolves. Alongside memorable characters like Baloo the bear, Bagheera the panther, and the menacing Shere Khan the tiger, Mowgli learns the laws of the jungle and navigates the complex relationships between animals and humans.

books.title: The-Adventures-of-Buster-Bear
books.author: Thornton W. Burgess
books.description: A sweet, easy-to-read nature tale that blends adventure and values. It teaches children about animals and how to treat others kindly, all while being fun and imaginative.

books.title: The Secret of the Old Clock [Revised Edition] (Nancy Drew Mystery [Revised] #1)
books.author: Adams, Harriet Stratemeyer  Writing under the pseudonym: Keene, Carolyn
books.description:
This is the rewritten in 1959 edition.


In this, the first book of the series, Nancy Drew is introduced to us, and searches for a missing will. Struggling relatives have no claim, only the evil already-rich ones are heirs by the only known will.


In the Harriet Adams rewrite, Nancy is depicted as a less impulsive, less headstrong girl of Stratemeyer and Mildred’s vision, to a milder, more sedate and refined girl— "more sugar and less spice", with an extensive wardrobe and a more charitable outlook. Helen now appears older, perhaps in preparation for her eventual "write-out" after Volume 4 of the revised series (no explanation is made in the original series) to introduce Bess and her cousin George. Readers have noted two figures illustrated in the same vein as the cousins appear in a 1959 illustration at a girls' camp. Racial stereotypes are omitted. Action is increased significantly and is faster-paced. Greater detail is given to develop Nancy and her home.

books.title: My-Book-of-Indoor-Games
books.author: Clarence Squareman
books.description: My Book of Indoor Games is a charming and practical collection of over 190 classic games, riddles, and activities for children and families to enjoy indoors. Written by Clarence Squareman, the book includes a variety of imaginative and clever games suited for playrooms, classrooms, rainy days, or small gatherings.

books.title: Aladdin-and-the-Magic-Lamp
books.author: unknown
books.description: "Aladdin and the Magic Lamp" is a beloved Middle Eastern folk tale, famously integrated into One Thousand and One Nights, that transcends generations as a classic example of children's fantasy literature. The story centers on Aladdin, a poor but cunning young man who discovers a magical lamp containing a powerful genie capable of granting wishes. With the genie's aid, Aladdin transforms his fortunes, winning the hand of a princess and amassing immense wealth, only to face the schemes of a wicked sorcerer who seeks to reclaim the lamp. The narrative is a captivating blend of magic, adventure, romance, and the enduring themes of good versus evil, highlighting the consequences of wishes and the triumph of wit and courage.

books.title: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (collection of short stories)
books.author: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle
books.description: First published in 1892, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes gathers twelve riveting cases in which the razor‑sharp detective and his stalwart companion Dr. Watson outwit blackmailers, thieves, and criminals of every stripe. From “A Scandal in Bohemia” to “The Speckled Band,” these stories showcase Arthur Conan Doyle’s masterful plotting, witty dialogue, and the enduring charisma of literature’s most famous sleuth.

books.title: Little Men
books.author: Louisa May Alcott
books.description: "Little Men," published in 1871 by Louisa May Alcott, is the charming and heartfelt sequel to her beloved "Little Women," picking up ten years later at Plumfield, the experimental school founded by Jo Bhaer (née March) and her husband, Professor Friedrich Bhaer. The novel chronicles the daily lives, adventures, and moral development of the diverse group of boys—some orphaned, some mischievous, some timid—who come under Jo's unconventional and nurturing care. Through a series of vignettes and gentle lessons, Alcott explores themes of education, discipline, empathy, and the power of love and understanding in shaping young characters into responsible and kind individuals. It's a warm, often humorous, and always insightful glimpse into the joys and challenges of raising children with a philosophy centered on personal growth rather than rigid rules.

books.title: Fifty-Two-Sunday-Dinners
books.author: Elizabeth O. Hiller
books.description:
Fifty-Two Sunday Dinners is a vintage cookbook offering a complete menu for every Sunday of the year, including appetizers, main courses, side dishes, desserts, and beverages.

Originally published in 1913, the book was created to help American families plan affordable, wholesome, and seasonally appropriate Sunday meals. Each menu is thoughtfully paired with simple recipes, focusing on practicality and balance, while using ingredients common in the early 20th century.

books.title: Pennsylvania-Dutch-Cooking
books.author: Unknown (published anonymously)
books.description:
Pennsylvania Dutch Cooking is a classic collection of over 200 traditional recipes from the Pennsylvania Dutch communities—descendants of German-speaking immigrants who settled in Pennsylvania in the 17th and 18th centuries.

The cookbook preserves the culinary heritage of Amish, Mennonite, and other rural families, reflecting their simple, hearty, and flavorful cooking styles. Originally distributed in pamphlet form or as a promotional piece, this version was digitized and made available by Project Gutenberg, confirming its public domain status.

books.title: Grimms'-Fairy-Tales
books.author: Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm
books.description: "Grimms' Fairy Tales," more formally known as Children's and Household Tales, is a world-renowned collection of folk tales meticulously gathered and published by German brothers Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm throughout the 19th century, with the first volume appearing in 1812. Far more than simple bedtime stories, these tales—including classics like "Cinderella," "Hansel and Gretel," "Little Red-Cap" (Little Red Riding Hood), and "Snow White"—preserve centuries of European oral tradition, often featuring dark, moralistic, and sometimes violent themes alongside elements of magic, transformation, and justice. The collection stands as a cornerstone of German and world literature, influencing countless subsequent works of fantasy and children's fiction, while also serving as a vital resource for the study of folklore, linguistics, and cultural history.

books.title: Tik-Tok-of-Oz
books.author: L. Frank Baum (1856–1919)
books.description: Tik-Tok of Oz, the eighth book in L. Frank Baum’s Oz series, follows the Shaggy Man on a quest to rescue his brother from the evil Nome King. He’s joined by Tik-Tok, a wind-up mechanical man; Betsy Bobbin, a girl from Oklahoma; her mule Hank; the ambitious Queen Ann of Oogaboo; and Polychrome, daughter of the Rainbow. Together, they journey through magical lands, face strange creatures like the dragon Quox, and overcome thrilling challenges across Oz.

books.title: The-Mouse's-Wedding
books.author: David Thomson or Lafcadio Hearn
books.description:
The Mouse’s Wedding is a delightful Japanese folk tale in which a wealthy mouse family seeks the “greatest being in the world” to marry their daughter. They first approach the sun, then the cloud, the wind, and finally a wall — each believed to be greater than the last. But in the end, the wall is no match for a mouse, who can dig through it. The moral? Sometimes, the most suitable match is found within your own kind.

This humorous and wise story teaches lessons about humility, self-awareness, and the value of understanding your place in the world.

books.title: The-Last-Generation
books.author: James Elroy Flecker (1884–1915)
books.description: The Last Generation: A Story of the Future (1908) is a dystopian novella in which humanity, seeking moral and intellectual perfection, embraces mass sterilization—choosing extinction. Through the eyes of a narrator in a future society, we witness a refined but emotionally hollow world, where people calmly accept their end. The story critiques utopian ideals and the loss of human purpose, foreshadowing classics like Brave New World and 1984.

books.title: Through-the-Looking-Glass
books.author: Lewis Carroll
books.description: "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There," published in 1871 by Lewis Carroll, is the brilliant sequel to Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, immersing readers once more in a world of enchanting illogic and whimsical delight. The story follows Alice as she steps through a mirror into an inverted, chess-themed landscape where everything is the opposite of what it seems. As she journeys across the chessboard, encountering an array of eccentric characters like Humpty Dumpty, the White Queen, and the Red Queen, Alice navigates a realm governed by peculiar rules of logic, language, and time. Celebrated for its ingenious wordplay, philosophical undertones, and imaginative satire, the novel is a timeless classic that continues to captivate readers with its unique blend of fantasy, literary nonsense, and sharp wit.

books.title: Lulu’s Library
books.author: Louisa May Alcott
books.description: "Lulu's Library" is a charming collection of children's short stories by the celebrated American author Louisa May Alcott, best known for Little Women. Published in multiple volumes starting in 1886, these tales were largely inspired by stories Alcott told to her niece, Lulu, whom she cared for. The "library" features a diverse array of whimsical and often moralistic narratives, blending imaginative adventures with everyday childhood experiences. From fairy tales like "The Frost King" to more realistic accounts of children's lives, the collection explores themes of kindness, imagination, friendship, and the subtle lessons learned during growing up, showcasing Alcott's gentle wit and her profound understanding of the joys and challenges of childhood.

books.title: The-Cozy-Lion
books.author: Frances Hodgson Burnett
books.description: The Cozy Lion is a charming fairy tale about a grumpy, spoiled lion who scares village children with his loud roars. When Queen Crosspatch, a wise fairy, steps in, she teaches him kindness and good manners. Through her guidance and a few funny mishaps, the lion becomes gentle and friendly—earning the love of the children he once frightened.

books.title: Behind the Scenes Or, Thirty Years a Slave and Four Years in the White House
books.author: Elizabeth Keckley
books.description:
Behind the Scenes: Or, Thirty Years a Slave and Four Years in the White House is the autobiography of Elizabeth Keckley, a formerly enslaved woman who became a successful dressmaker and confidante to First Lady Mary Todd Lincoln during the American Civil War.

The book offers a unique dual perspective:

The harrowing realities of slavery: Keckley recounts her experiences as an enslaved person, detailing the brutal treatment she endured and witnessed, her yearning for freedom, and her eventual self-emancipation through hard work and determination.

An intimate look at the Lincoln White House: After gaining her freedom, Keckley established herself as a prominent modiste (dressmaker) in Washington D.C., eventually serving Mary Todd Lincoln. Her narrative provides an unparalleled "behind the scenes" glimpse into the personal lives, struggles, and emotional complexities of the Lincoln family during one of the most tumultuous periods in American history. She offers insights into Mary Lincoln's personality, her grief, and her relationship with her husband, Abraham Lincoln.
books.file_name: Behind the Scenes Or, Thirty Years a Slave and Four Years in the White House.pdf

books.title: The Rise Of Product Operations eBook
books.author: PENDO + Product Collective
books.description: At its core, Product Ops is the intersection of product (including product design), engineering, and customer success (CS). It exists to support the R&D team and their go-to-market counterparts to improve alignment, communication, and processes around product development, launch, and iteration.

books.title: An-ethical-philosophy-of-life-presented-in-its-main-outlines
books.author: Felix Adler
books.description: "An Ethical Philosophy of Life" by Felix Adler is a profound work of moral philosophy that outlines a comprehensive system for ethical living, presented from the unique perspective of the founder of the Ethical Culture movement. Published in the early 20th century, the book critiques dogmatic and creed-based approaches to morality, instead advocating for an ethics grounded in the intrinsic worth and dignity of every individual. Adler argues that the purpose of life is to elicit the unique personality and potential in oneself and others through reciprocal relationships and active engagement in building a more humane world. The book delves into both personal ethics (addressing issues like sickness, sorrow, and sin) and social ethics (examining the family, state, and international relations), ultimately offering a framework for navigating complex moral dilemmas and living a meaningful life through "deed, not creed."

books.title: Think-And-Grow-Rich
books.author: Napoleon Hill
books.description: “Think and Grow Rich” by Napoleon Hill is a classic success manual first published in 1937. Based on 25 years of research and interviews with wealthy individuals like Henry Ford and Thomas Edison, the book teaches powerful principles of goal-setting, belief, persistence, and money mindset. Its timeless ideas continue to inspire readers to achieve personal and financial success.

books.title: Pir e Kamil
books.author: Umera Ahmed
books.description: The story centers on two main characters, Imama Hashim and Salaar Sikandar, who are on individual journeys of faith, love, and self-discovery. Imama, a young woman with strong religious beliefs, and Salaar, a brilliant but troubled young man with complex questions about life and faith, find their paths unexpectedly intertwined.
books.file_name: Pir e Kamil By Umera Ahmed.pdf

books.title: The Clean Coder - A Code of Conduct for Professional Programmers - 1st Edition (2011)
books.author: Bob Martin
books.description:
Programmers who endure and succeed amidst swirling uncertainty and nonstop pressure share a common attribute: 

They care deeply about the practice of creating software. They treat it as a craft. They are professionals.


**In The Clean Coder**:
A Code of Conduct for Professional Programmers, legendary software expert Robert C. Martin introduces the disciplines, techniques, tools, and practices of true software craftsmanship. This book is packed with practical advice–about everything from estimating and coding to refactoring and testing. It covers much more than technique: It is about attitude. Martin shows how to approach software development with honor, self-respect, and pride; work well and work clean; communicate and estimate faithfully; face difficult decisions with clarity and honesty; and understand that deep knowledge comes with a responsibility to act.

**Readers will learn**

- What it means to behave as a true software craftsman
- How to deal with conflict, tight schedules, and unreasonable managers
- How to get into the flow of coding, and get past writer’s block
- How to handle unrelenting pressure and avoid burnout
- How to combine enduring attitudes with new development paradigms
- How to manage your time, and avoid blind alleys, marshes, bogs, and swamps
- How to foster environments where programmers and teams can thrive
- When to say “No”–and how to say it
- When to say “Yes”–and what yes really means


Great software is something to marvel at: powerful, elegant, functional, a pleasure to work with as both a developer and as a user. 

Great software isn’t written by machines. It is written by professionals with an unshakable commitment to craftsmanship. The Clean Coder will help you become one of them–and earn the pride and fulfillment that they alone possess.
books.file_name: The Clean Coder - A Code of Conduct for Professional Programmers - 1st Edition (2011).pdf

books.title: Uncle-Tom's-Cabin
books.author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
books.description: Originally published in 1852, Uncle Tom’s Cabin is a powerful anti-slavery novel that helped fuel the abolitionist movement in the United States. The story follows the trials of Uncle Tom, a devout and noble enslaved man, and other characters whose lives are impacted by slavery. Through vivid storytelling and moral conviction, Harriet Beecher Stowe exposed the cruelty of the slave system, influencing generations and sparking social change.

books.title: The-Adventure-of-the-Cardboard-Box
books.author: Arthur Conan Doyle
books.description: "The Adventure of the Cardboard Box" is a classic Sherlock Holmes short story by Arthur Conan Doyle, first published in 1893. The peculiar case begins when Miss Susan Cushing receives a package containing two freshly severed human ears, prompting Scotland Yard's initial bewilderment. Holmes, however, swiftly deduces that this gruesome delivery is a coded message linked to a complex and tragic past involving a clandestine affair, a jealous husband, and a bitter act of revenge. Through his unparalleled powers of observation and logical deduction, the master detective unravels a dark tale of betrayal and murder, providing a chilling insight into the depths of human passion and vengeance.

books.title: Recalibrating Stigma Sociologies of Health and Illness
books.author: Gareth M. Thomas, Oli Williams, Tanisha Spratt, Amy Chandler
books.description: "Recalibrating Stigma: Sociologies of Health and Illness" is an insightful academic collection that challenges and refines the conceptualization of stigma within the fields of health and illness. Featuring analyses from various scholars, the book explores how stigma operates across diverse issues, including mental health, racism, HIV, obesity, and disability. It aims to stimulate new conversations and highlight the crucial contributions of sociological approaches to understanding and addressing the pervasive impact of stigma in society.
books.file_name: Recalibrating Stigma Sociologies of Health and Illness.pdf

books.title: Salome
books.author: Oscar Wilde
books.description:
"Salomé" is a one-act tragedy written by Oscar Wilde in French in 1891, and first published in 1893 with an English translation following in 1894.

The play is a highly stylized and symbolist re-imagining of the biblical story of Salome, Herod Antipas, and John the Baptist (Iokanaan). Set in ancient Judea, it centers on the young, beautiful princess Salomé's obsessive and ultimately fatal desire for the prophet Iokanaan, who repulses her advances.

books.title: Aesop for Children
books.author: Milo Winter
books.description: Aesop's Fables are a collection of short stories that teach important life lessons. The stories often feature animals that can talk and act like humans, like a clever fox or a wise owl. Each story has a moral at the end, which is a lesson about how to be a better person. For example, one fable teaches that "slow and steady wins the race," while another might remind you that "honesty is the best policy." Even though the stories are really old (some go back thousands of years!), they still apply to our lives today. They're fun, easy to read, and full of wisdom that can help with everything from friendships to schoolwork.

books.title: Kashmir
books.author: Sir Francis Edward Younghusband
books.description: Published in 1909, this beautifully illustrated travel book offers a vivid and personal account of Kashmir through the eyes of British explorer Sir Francis Younghusband. Enhanced by Major Molyneux’s watercolor paintings, the book captures the natural beauty, culture, and charm of the Kashmir Valley during the British Raj.

books.title: Educating-by-Story-Telling
books.author: Katherine Dunlap Cather
books.description: "Educating by Story-Telling" by Katherine Dunlap Cather is a foundational educational text from the early 20th century that advocates for the power of narrative as a pedagogical tool. The book outlines how storytelling can be effectively integrated into the curriculum to enhance children's learning, foster moral development, stimulate imagination, and deepen their engagement with various subjects. Cather, drawing from extensive experience, provides practical guidance for educators and parents on selecting and telling stories that resonate with children's developmental stages and interests, ultimately aiming to make education a more enjoyable and impactful experience.

books.title: The Book of Dragons
books.author: E. Nesbit
books.description: "The Book of Dragons" by E. Nesbit is a classic collection of 8 magical and funny dragon stories for children. Each tale features a unique adventure with dragons, imagination, and light-hearted lessons — perfect for young readers and fantasy lovers.

books.title: Pride and Prejudice
books.author: Jane Austen
books.description: "Pride and Prejudice" is a timeless romantic novel by Jane Austen that follows the spirited Elizabeth Bennet and the proud Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy as they navigate societal pressures, class distinctions, and their own initial misjudgments to eventually find love. Set in early 19th-century England, the story is a witty and insightful critique of marriage, social status, and personal growth.

books.title: The-Child's-Book-of-American-Biography
books.author: Mary Stoyell Stimpson
books.description: "The Child's Book of American Biography" by Mary Stoyell Stimpson is a classic early 20th-century American children's nonfiction book that provides short, accessible biographies of significant figures in U.S. history, such as George Washington, Benjamin Franklin, and Abraham Lincoln. Written in a simple, engaging style and often accompanied by illustrations, the book aims to introduce young readers to the lives and contributions of these historical personalities, fostering an understanding of American heritage and inspiring a sense of national pride through their stories.

books.title: Ideal Husband
books.author: Oscar Wilde
books.description: "An Ideal Husband" is a four-act play by Oscar Wilde, first performed in 1895. It is a brilliant example of a Victorian-era comedy of manners interwoven with elements of melodrama and biting social satire.

books.title: Beauty-and-the-Beast
books.author: Anonymous
books.description: Beauty and the Beast is a classic fairy tale about love, kindness, and inner beauty. It tells the story of a selfless girl, Beauty, who chooses to live with a terrifying Beast in order to save her father. As time passes, she discovers that true beauty lies within. This Urdu version brings the timeless tale to life for young readers and adults alike, full of magic, emotion, and moral lessons.

books.title: Language-of-Flowers
books.author: Kate Greenaway
books.description:
The Language of Flowers by Kate Greenaway is a charming Victorian-era book that pairs flower names with their symbolic meanings (also known as “floriography”). Each flower is illustrated in Greenaway’s signature delicate watercolor style, often accompanied by short verses or poetic definitions.
It was used as a decorative gift book and to help people send “secret messages” through flower arrangements, which was a popular custom in the 19th century.

books.title: Daddy Long Legs
books.author: Jean Webster
books.description: Daddy-Long-Legs is a charming epistolary novel (told through letters) that follows Jerusha “Judy” Abbott, a bright and witty orphan girl who is sent to college by an anonymous benefactor. She affectionately nicknames him "Daddy-Long-Legs" after seeing only his shadow. As she grows in confidence and intellect, Judy writes humorous and heartfelt letters to her mysterious sponsor, sharing her personal growth, college experiences, and philosophical reflections. The novel explores themes of independence, education, women's rights, and the importance of kindness.

books.title: Fish-Stories
books.author: Henry Abbott
books.description:
Fish Stories is a collection of humorous and engaging short stories centered around fishing, outdoor life, and the personalities that inhabit those spaces. Written with charm and wit, Henry Abbott brings together tales that celebrate the joys and absurdities of angling culture. The stories reflect both real and exaggerated fishing experiences, often poking fun at the “tall tales” fishermen are known for.
These stories offer a window into early 20th-century recreational life in America, particularly for fishing enthusiasts. It’s light, fun, and sometimes satirical in tone.

books.title: The-Tale-of-Benny-Badger
books.author: Arthur Scott Bailey
books.description: The Tale of Benny Badger is part of Arthur Scott Bailey's beloved Tuck-Me-In Tales series, which introduces young readers to animals in an entertaining and gentle way. Benny Badger is a curious and somewhat mischievous little fellow who gets into trouble while exploring his surroundings. His adventures take him across the fields and through burrows as he learns life lessons through nature and other woodland creatures.

books.title: 'Smiles'
books.author: Eliot H. Robinson
books.description: "Smiles" is an early 20th-century American romance novel set in the picturesque Cumberland Mountains of Kentucky. It tells the heartwarming story of a young woman named Smiles, who finds herself in a rugged yet charming community, and the journey of love and self-discovery that unfolds as she interacts with the local inhabitants. The novel is characterized by its vivid regional setting and its focus on enduring affection and the simple beauties of life.

books.title: saMas Kids' Mag, Vol. 2, Issue 1, (Jan 2025)
books.author: Children Magazine Editorial Team
books.description: saMas Charity Children Magazine, Vol. 2, Issue 1, Jan 2025
books.file_name: saMas Charity Children Magazine, Vol. 2, Issue 1, Jan 2025 .pdf

books.title: Kalidasa, Translations of Shakuntala, and Other Works
books.author: Arthur W. Ryder
books.description:
"Kalidasa, Translations of Shakuntala, and Other Works" by Arthur W. Ryder is a collection of English translations of seminal works by Kalidasa, widely considered ancient India's greatest Sanskrit poet and dramatist, often referred to as the "Shakespeare of India."

The centerpiece of the collection is "Shakuntala" (or Abhijnanasakuntalam), Kalidasa's most famous play. It is a beautiful and poignant romantic drama that tells the story of King Dushyanta and the hermit-girl Shakuntala, their secret marriage, their separation due to a sage's curse, and their eventual reunion, often involving themes of love, loss, nature, and divine intervention.

books.title: The-Hollow-Tree-and-Deep-Woods-Book
books.author: An American author known for children's literature and as the biographer of Mark Twain
books.description:
This book is a collection of short stories told by various woodland animals who live in the Hollow Tree in the Deep Woods. The main characters—Mr. Dog, Mr. Possum, Mr. Coon, and the Old Black Crow—gather to tell amusing and often wise tales about life in the woods. It blends gentle humor, friendship, and moral lessons in a delightful, illustrated format ideal for children and nostalgic adults.
The stories are designed to be read aloud and often contain charming sketches and warm storytelling in a folksy style.

books.title: Voices from the Past
books.author: Paul Alexander Bartlett
books.description: "A collection of five historical novels written in the form of journals by the Greek poet Sappho of Lesbos, Christ, Leonardo da Vinci, Shakespeare, and Lincoln, integrating their thought, writings, and the testimony of others"--Provided by publisher.

books.title: Benjamin Franklin-Autobiography
books.author: Benjamin Franklin
books.description: The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin is an unfinished account of Benjamin Franklin's life, written by himself from 1771 until shortly before his death in 1790. Though often called his "Autobiography," Franklin sometimes referred to it as his "Memoirs." It's considered one of the most famous and influential autobiographies ever written.

books.title: The Magic Pitcher - Hindu Tales from the Sanskrit
books.author: Nancy Bell
books.description: A collection of 9 Hindu tales for children. Each tale has a few questions at the end of it. The stories include: The Magic Pitcher: The Story of a Cat, a Mouse, a Lizard and an Owl; A Royal Thief-Catcher; The Magic Shoes and Staff; The Jewelled Arrow; The Beetle and the Silken Thread; A Crow and His Three Friends; A Clever Thief; and, The Hermit's Daughter.

books.title: Chatterbox-Stories-of-Natural-History
books.author: Rev. J.G. Wood, a well-known 19th-century naturalist and writer.
books.description: Chatterbox Stories of Natural History" is a delightful blend of educational writing and storytelling. It was part of the famous Chatterbox annual series, a Victorian-era children's magazine known for its high-quality stories, illustrations, and moral lessons.

books.title: The-Tale-of-Ferdinand-Frog
books.author: Scott Bailey
books.description: The Tale of Ferdinand Frog" is a charming children’s story about a cheerful, boastful frog who lives in a peaceful country pond. Ferdinand enjoys singing, telling stories, and showing off his jumps. Through his amusing adventures with other woodland and pond creatures—like birds, fish, and insects—children learn about animal behavior, the importance of friendship, and the trouble that can come from bragging. Written in a warm, conversational style and accompanied by classic black-and-white illustrations, this book is ideal for read-aloud moments and part of the beloved Tuck-Me-In Tales series.

books.title: Fruits-of-Queensland
books.author: A.H. Benson
books.description: Fruits of Queensland" is a practical and richly illustrated guide to the fruit varieties grown in Queensland, Australia. Aimed at farmers and students, it offers detailed descriptions of native and exotic fruits, advice on cultivation, suitable climates and soils, and notes on their commercial value. First published in the early 20th century, it remains a valuable historical resource, showcasing the region’s agricultural diversity and providing timeless insights for gardeners, researchers, and those interested in Australia's horticultural history.

books.title: The Boy Chums in the Forest; Or, Hunting for Plume Birds in the Florida Everglades
books.author: Wilmer M. Ely
books.description:
This book is part of the Boy Chums adventure series, which follows two friends, Charley and Walter, through thrilling experiences. In this installment, the boys explore the wilds of the Florida Everglades, on a quest to hunt plume birds—valuable birds once prized for their feathers used in ladies' hats.
Along the way, they face natural dangers, meet mysterious characters, and learn survival skills in the forest. The story reflects the spirit of adventure and the fascination with nature and exploration typical of early 20th-century juvenile fiction.

books.title: The-Human-Side-of-Animals
books.author: Royal Dixon
books.description: The Human Side of Animals" by Royal Dixon is a heartfelt and philosophical look at animal life, arguing that animals feel emotions, show intelligence, and have unique personalities—just like humans. Through vivid stories and observations, Dixon explores love, loyalty, grief, and moral behavior in animals, urging readers to treat them with compassion. Though not scientific, the book influenced early views on animal rights and remains a powerful reminder of our ethical duty toward the natural world.

books.title: The-Tale-of-Jasper-Jay
books.author: Scott Bailey
books.description: The Tale of Jasper Jay" is a lighthearted children's story about a noisy, mischievous blue jay who often causes trouble in the Green Forest. Through fun and gentle adventures with characters like Mr. Chippy, Solomon Owl, and Buddy Brown-Thrasher, Jasper learns important lessons about honesty, respect, and good manners. Told in short, engaging chapters, the book is perfect for young readers and bedtime storytelling.

books.title: Bird-Children
books.author: Elizabeth Gordon
books.description: Bird Children" is a charming illustrated book that introduces children to 84 bird species through short, playful poems and vibrant illustrations by M.T. Ross. Each bird is personified as a child in bird-inspired costume, making learning fun and imaginative. A companion to Elizabeth Gordon’s “Flower Children,” it blends nature, art, and rhyme to spark curiosity and appreciation for birds.

books.title: Nights-With-Uncle-Remus
books.author: Joel Chandler Harris
books.description:
Nights with Uncle Remus is a sequel to Uncle Remus: His Songs and Sayings. It features a collection of African American folktales told by the fictional character Uncle Remus, an elderly Black man who shares trickster tales and animal fables from the Southern U.S. The main stars are Br’er Rabbit, Br’er Fox, and other clever creatures who outwit danger using intelligence and mischief.
Told in Southern dialect and framed as nightly storytelling sessions, the tales entertain while subtly revealing themes of wit, survival, and community. The book preserves oral traditions passed down by enslaved African Americans.

books.title: The-Dunwich-Horror
books.author: Howard Phillips Lovecraft (H. P. Lovecraft)
books.description: In the remote New England village of Dunwich, strange events unfold after the birth of Wilbur Whateley, an unusually fast-growing child born under mysterious circumstances. As he grows older, it becomes clear that Wilbur is not entirely human. Obsessed with the forbidden tome, the Necronomicon, and with summoning the cosmic entity Yog-Sothoth, Wilbur meets a grisly end. However, an even more terrifying truth is revealed — something invisible and monstrous roams the hills of Dunwich, and it is up to a group of scholars to stop it before it destroys the world.

books.title: Varney-the-Vampire
books.author: James Malcolm Rymer
books.description:
Varney the Vampire is one of the earliest full-length works to feature a vampire as a central character. The story revolves around Sir Francis Varney, a vampiric nobleman who stalks the Bannerworth family, preying on them in their ancestral home. The tale is full of dramatic twists: duels, abductions, mistaken identities, and betrayals. Over time, Varney emerges as a complex, sometimes sympathetic figure — more tragic than purely evil.
The novel spans over 220 chapters and 667,000 words, making it one of the longest works in English literature. Despite its repetitive style (due to its serialized format), it laid the groundwork for modern vampire fiction — introducing tropes like:
Fanged bites on the neck
Hypnotic power over victims
A vampire who struggles with his condition
The gothic, gloomy atmosphere

books.title: Sense And Sensibility
books.author: Jane Austen
books.description: "Sense and Sensibility," Jane Austen's debut novel, published in 1811, elegantly explores the contrasting temperaments of the Dashwood sisters, Elinor and Marianne, as they navigate love, loss, and societal expectations in Regency England. Elinor, embodying "sense," approaches life with prudence, discretion, and a controlled demeanor, even in the face of emotional turmoil. In contrast, Marianne, representing "sensibility," is guided by intense emotion, romantic idealism, and an open display of her feelings. The novel follows their individual romantic entanglements and heartbreaks after they are left impoverished, highlighting the societal pressures concerning marriage and financial security, while subtly critiquing the extremes of both excessive rationalism and uncontrolled passion.

books.title: The Man Who Was Thursday
books.author: G.K. Chesterton
books.description: The Man Who Was Thursday is a surreal and philosophical mystery novel that blurs the line between reality and illusion. The story follows Gabriel Syme, a poet-turned-detective, who infiltrates a secret anarchist council where each member is named after a day of the week. What begins as a spy thriller evolves into a profound meditation on chaos, identity, and the nature of good and evil. Chesterton’s clever wit and metaphysical twists make this a unique and thought-provoking classic.

books.title: War and Peace
books.author: Leo Tolstoy
books.description: War and Peace is a sweeping epic of love, war, and destiny set during the Napoleonic invasion of Russia. Blending historical fact with fiction, Tolstoy follows the lives of several Russian aristocratic families, particularly the Rostovs, Bolkonskys, and Bezukhovs. The novel explores deep themes of fate, free will, morality, and the human condition — all set against one of history’s most dramatic backdrops. It is widely regarded as one of the greatest novels ever written.

books.title: The-Book-of-Courage
books.author: John Thomson Faris
books.description: The Book of Courage is an inspirational collection by John T. Faris that shares real-life stories and moral lessons to encourage strength and faith in the face of adversity. Blending biography, history, and spiritual insight, each chapter highlights a theme like bravery, endurance, or loyalty—illustrated through uplifting anecdotes.

books.title: The-New-Dr.-Price-Cookbook
books.author: Baking Powder Factory, Chicago, USA
books.description: The New Dr. Price Cookbook (1908) is a vintage American cookbook featuring over 400 simple, practical recipes—from baked goods to meat, vegetables, and desserts. Created to promote Dr. Price’s Baking Powder, it emphasizes economical, healthy home cooking for early 20th-century households.

books.title: Recipes-for-Eatmor-Fresh-Cranberries
books.author: American Cranberry Exchange
books.description: Recipes for Eatmor Fresh Cranberries is a vintage mid-20th-century recipe booklet featuring creative and practical ways to use fresh cranberries. It includes quick sauces, fruity relishes, pies, sherbet, and holiday decorations. Designed as a promotional tool for Eatmor Cranberries, the recipes are simple, seasonal, and ideal for holiday meals.

books.title: Migration of Birds, Frederick C. Lincoln
books.author: Frederick C. Lincoln, Ph.D.
books.description: Migration of Birds by Frederick C. Lincoln is a classic scientific guide that explains the how, why, when, and where of bird migration across North America. Originally published in 1935 and later revised, it explores bird instincts, flight routes (like the four major flyways), seasonal timing, and methods used to study migration—such as bird banding and early radar. It combines clear explanations with scientific insight, making it valuable for both experts and curious readers.
books.file_name: Migration of Birds, Frederick C. Lincoln.pdf

books.title: What to Draw and How to Draw It
books.author: Edwin George Lutz
books.description: What to Draw and How to Draw It (1913) by Edwin George Lutz is a classic beginner’s drawing guide that teaches fundamental techniques through simple step-by-step lessons. Aimed at children and novices, it breaks down complex subjects like animals, people, and objects into basic shapes, encouraging observation and creativity.
books.file_name: 12. Learn to Draw; What To Draw and How To Draw It (Presentation) Author E. G. Lutz.pdf

books.title: Practice Book, Donna Burk
books.author: Donna Burk
books.description: Practice Book by Donna Burk is a supplemental math workbook designed for young learners, primarily kindergarten to early elementary students. It features a variety of worksheets that help reinforce fundamental math skills such as counting, sorting, number patterns, and basic addition and subtraction.
